title: 103_hr2668
content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Investment Demonstration Act of 1993" and includes a Section 8 Community Investment Demonstration Program. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a demonstration program to provide project-based rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for low-income families in housing financed by eligible pension funds. The assistance will be project-based and attached to eligible housing. Project-based rental assistance will be provided for a term of 60 to 180 months by the Secretary to eligible housing owners. The contract rents will be determined by the Secretary, considering construction, rehabilitation, or acquisition costs, but cannot exceed the rent permitted under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. The Secretary may provide assistance for eligible housing projects, including multifamily housing owned or mortgaged by the Secretary, severely distressed public housing projects, troubled projects, and multifamily housing in need of assistance. The Secretary may provide assistance for eligible housing projects, including multifamily housing projects located in empowerment zones, projects for homeless persons or families, and projects with financing commitments from eligible pension funds. The housing must meet standards for securitization and financing set by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide assistance for eligible housing projects, including multifamily housing in empowerment zones, for homeless individuals or families, and projects with financing commitments from eligible pension funds. The owner must assure the Secretary of owning or controlling a suitable site for construction within 12 months. The housing must comply with environmental laws, be consistent with the approved housing affordability strategy under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The Secretary allows owners of eligible housing to jointly apply for assistance with eligible pension funds. The application must include details about the housing project, location, financing terms, requested assistance amount, and other required information. The selection and determination of assistance will be made by the Secretary. The Secretary selects eligible housing for assistance from applications submitted and determines the appropriate amount to maintain affordability and feasibility. During the initial 6-month period, the Secretary may not provide more than 50 percent of the available amounts for assistance. The Secretary selects eligible housing for assistance based on applications and determines the appropriate amount. Project-based assistance provided shall not affect percentage limitations under the United States Housing Act of 1937. Assistance in property disposition programs may have a contract term of less than 15 years under certain conditions. The Secretary selects eligible housing for assistance based on applications and determines the appropriate amount. Project-based assistance provided shall not affect percentage limitations under the United States Housing Act of 1937. A significant amount of funds may be used for the disposition of eligible housing under section 203 of the Housing and Community Development Amendments of 1978. The Comptroller General of the United States evaluates the effectiveness of the demonstration under this section and submits reports to Congress. The Secretary submits annual reports to Congress summarizing activities, housing assisted, assistance amounts, findings, and recommendations under the section. Reports are due within specific timeframes. Annual reports summarizing activities, housing assisted, assistance amounts, findings, and recommendations under the section must be submitted within 3 months after the fiscal year ends. Definitions include "eligible housing" meeting specific requirements and "eligible pension fund" as any trust, fund, plan, or entity investing funds for employee benefits. The Secretary will issue final regulations within 45 days of enactment, no new assistance commitments after September 30, 1998. Funding allocation for the community investment program is limited to $100,000,000. The House of Representatives passed the bill on August 2, 1993.
